Dialogues: Like any other wave, orbitals have their ups and downs.
The number of ups and downs is the principal quantum number, n.
Where the wave function becomes 0, there is a “node.”  Orbitals have as many nodes as n - 1.
One type of node is the radial node, which is spherical.
They can be seen more clearly in a cross section.
This graph shows Ψ² against the distance from the nucleus.
If you take a snapshot of the orbital, the wave will collapse into a particle. You’ll be able to get the electron location.
Although Ψ has no physical meaning, Ψ² shows how probable each point is.
Notice how the x-intercepts line up with the nodes.
The radii with no snapshot-probability form radial nodes.
Many other orbitals have radial nodes.
